Approximately 9600 weapons were found to be in working condition and ready for use. Out of these, only 1364 were percussion weapons. The distribution of these weapons from the Arsenal is not entirely clear, but it is believed that the 5th, 6th, 7th, and 8th Arkansas Infantry Regiments, which were enlisted in June 1861, were equipped with M1816/M1822 .69 caliber flintlocks. Other units such as the 9th and 10th Arkansas Infantry, four companies of Kelly's 9th Arkansas Battalion, and the 3rd Arkansas Cavalry Regiment were issued flintlock Hall's Rifles. Additionally, the 1st and 2nd Arkansas Mounted Rifles of Van Dorn's Army of the West were also armed with M1822 flintlocks from the Little Rock Arsenal. When the 11th and 12th Arkansas Infantry Regiments were mustered in at Little Rock, the supply of arms had significantly dwindled, leaving only outdated weapons available.

In April and May 1862, the majority of the equipment, arms, and machinery from the Little Rock Arsenal were relocated east of the Mississippi River under the directive of Maj. Gen. Earl Van Dorn. The whereabouts of these items became unknown at that juncture. It seems that the equipment was transported along the river to Napoleon, Arkansas, and subsequently to Jackson, Mississippi. It is likely that the equipment met its demise during the Vicksburg campaign in the early summer of 1863.

In May 1862, Major General Thomas C. Hindman was appointed to lead the Arkansas district, where he discovered a severe lack of military resources. To address this issue, Hindman set up a new armory in Arkadelphia and reinvigorated the Little Rock Arsenal to serve as a hub for gathering and producing small arms, as well as storing ammunition. Hindman documented his efforts by stating:

Machinery was constructed to produce percussion caps and firearms, with a focus on maintaining a high standard despite the limited quantity manufactured. Additionally, efforts were made to operate lead mines, establish a chemical laboratory, and produce various medicinal products to support the Ordnance Department. These activities were primarily centered around Arkadelphia on the Ouachita River, approximately 75 miles south of Little Rock. The tools, machinery, and materials were either collected gradually or crafted through manual labor. Prior to this initiative, Arkansas had not undertaken such projects for the Government, apart from small arms manufacturing. General Van Dorn had previously removed the machinery for this purpose. Due to the lack of capital and citizen involvement, extra resources, including lead, caps, and supplies, were acquired through donations, purchases, and impressments from the residents of Little Rock and its surroundings.

The ammunition, along with what I had brought, was quickly readied for use at the Laboratory set up at the Little Rock Arsenal for this purpose. To highlight the dire shortage of materials in the area, it should be noted that public documents from the State Library had to be utilized for cartridge paper. Gunsmiths were enlisted or drafted, tools were bought or confiscated, and the process of repairing the damaged firearms I had brought and a similar number found at Little Rock began immediately. However, upon assessing the progress and witnessing the determination of the men, I concluded that a force of 500 could withstand Fitch, and I resolved to lead the remaining roughly 1500 to General Rust as soon as shotguns and rifles from Little Rock could replace the majority's current arms of pikes and lances. It took two days before this transition could be completed.

In August 1862, the Confederate ordnance establishment in Little Rock was reactivated. General Hindman, seeking a suitable leader, enlisted Lieutenant John W. Dunnington from the Confederate Navy. Lt. Dunnington, previously in charge of the gunboat C.S.S. Ponchartrain, brought to Little Rock for conversion to an ironclad, was chosen to oversee the ordnance works. Despite receiving pay from the Confederate Navy Department, Lt. Dunnington assumed control of all Confederate ordnance operations, including artillery duties, in Little Rock with the title of lieutenant colonel.

The "Returns for the month of August, 1862, at Little Rock Arsenal, C.S.A.," as documented by Lt. Col. Dunnington in Vol. 149, Chapter IV of the "Captured Rebel Ordnance Records," provide valuable insights into the extent of Confederate ordnance operations at Little Rock during this significant period. Lt. Col. Dunnington noted that upon assuming command at the Post, all resources had been relocated to Arkadelphia, and there was a lack of personnel, operational shops for weapon repairs, or ammunition production. The procurement of materials, tools, and the hiring of workers were necessary tasks that initiated towards the end of the month.

Dunnington led a military contingent in Little Rock comprising of four officers: Major John B. Lockman, Captain C.C. Green, and 2nd Lt. W.W. Murphy. Alongside them were 20 enlisted men and a civilian team including a foreman, 2 clerks, 3 gunsmiths specializing in small arms repair, a laboratorian, 26 laborers working in the ammunition laboratory, and a carpenter tasked with constructing packing boxes.

In August 1862, the following tasks were completed: manufacturing a pair of musket bullet molds, producing 10,000 buck and ball shot cartridges, fixing 750 muskets, shotguns, and rifles, receiving and repairing ordnance supplies, carrying out guard, office, and police responsibilities, and inspecting posts in Camden and Arkadelphia.

Until November 1862, Lt. Col. Dunnington oversaw the construction of his projects in Little Rock. At that time, Captain Sanford C. Faulkner, known for composing The Arkansas Traveler, took over the Arsenal. It is assumed that Dunnington then resumed his naval responsibilities on the Ponchartrain.

The key highlights from the "Summary of Work" above and the subsequent months are that the primary ammunition produced was "buck & ball," revealing that the prevalent firearms in use were .69 caliber smoothbores and shotguns. Additionally, around one-sixth or more of the total small arms ammunition was designated for flintlock weapons, suggesting that at least a sixth of the Confederate soldiers in the area still carried outdated flintlock firearms.

The records detailing the work accomplished at Little Rock Arsenal under the C.S.A. maintained a consistent pace and volume between August 1862 and August 1863. The report for August 1863 includes a foreboding entry stating that towards the end of the month, most of the supplies at the Arsenal were packed and dispatched to Arkadelphia as per the orders of the Chief of Ordnance, District of Arkansas. This event signifies the commencement of relocating ordnance operations from Little Rock, which eventually led to the city's surrender to the advancing Federal forces of Frederick Steele's Arkansas Expedition on September 11, 1863.
In 1864, following the Union Army's recapture of Little Rock and the arsenal, General Fredrick Steele led 8,500 troops from the arsenal to initiate the Camden Expedition.
The arsenal was temporarily taken over again by supporters of Joseph Brooks amid the Brooks-Baxter conflict in 1874.

In 1873, the structure underwent a name change to Little Rock Barracks and was repurposed to accommodate married officers and their families. Significant modifications were made to both the interior and exterior of the building. Originally, access was limited to a rear basement door, and a tower was utilized for moving munitions between levels. By 1868, enhancements such as front and rear porches, interior walls, and stairs were introduced, with some elements like the central staircase still existing today. It was in 1880 when Douglas MacArthur, the son of Captain Arthur MacArthur, was born on the northwest upper floor of this building during his father's military posting there.

During the 1880s, the federal government initiated the closure of numerous small arsenals nationwide in favor of constructing smaller ones in proximity to railroads for swift deployment. The arsenal commander at the Little Rock site was informed from Washington that it must be vacated by October 1, 1890. Subsequently, on April 12, 1893, the tower building and adjacent structures were exchanged with the city of Little Rock for 1,000 acres (4 km²) in North Little Rock, with the condition that the land and building be exclusively designated for public park use. The swapped land was situated in Big Rock Mountain on the north side of the Arkansas River, which is now known as North Little Rock. This location was later developed into Fort Logan H. Roots, and all original buildings surrounding the Tower Building were subsequently demolished.

In 1894, the Tower Building became the new home of the Little Rock Æsthetic Club, one of the oldest women's societies west of the Mississippi River. The relocation was driven by a growing membership and the necessity for larger, more permanent meeting spaces. The previous year, club members collaborated with women's organizations statewide to fund the furnishing of the Arkansas Building at the Columbian Exposition in The Chicago World's Fair. Following the fair, items from the exhibition were showcased in the Tower Building, where the Æsthetic Club convened in the designated "Columbian Room."

With the exception of gatherings held by the Æsthetic Club, the Tower Building stood vacant for nearly five decades and experienced considerable decay. The Æsthetic Club played a crucial role in offering financial assistance during this time, covering the electricity expenses even throughout the challenging period of the Great Depression. To this day, the Æsthetic Club continues to operate from its headquarters situated in the Tower Building.

Throughout the early 20th century, the building and the adjacent park were utilized for various public purposes. Specifically, the Tower Building functioned as the headquarters for the United Confederate Veterans Reunion from May 15 to 18, 1911. This event attracted over 106,000 Civil War veterans, marking the largest popular gathering in the city's history at that time. The veterans were accommodated in the building or camped in the park, which had transformed into a favored camping spot. Subsequently, the Tower Building was repurposed as an armory for the Arkansas National Guard. In 1912, the second floor of the Tower Building was repurposed as Little Rock's inaugural public library. Additionally, a fire station was erected in the park in 1917, although it has since been demolished. A band shell, named after H. H. Foster, was also constructed in the park during this period but no longer stands. In 1936, the Works Progress Administration constructed the Museum of Fine Arts, now known as the Arkansas Arts Center, just south of the Tower Building.

In 1970, the arsenal was officially recognized and added to the National Register of Historic Places. Its connection to the Camden Expedition of 1864 makes it eligible for potential inclusion in the Camden Expedition Sites National Historic Landmark, which was established in 1994.

In 1942, the Tower Building underwent renovations with support from the Æsthetic Club, Little Rock philanthropist Frederick W. Allsop, and the Works Progress Administration. It was transformed into the new location for The Arkansas Museum of Natural History and Antiquities, previously housed in Little Rock City Hall. The museum remained in the Tower Building for around fifty-five years. The area surrounding the building, formerly known as Arsenal Park and later renamed City Park, was officially renamed MacArthur Park in 1942 to honor Douglas MacArthur, thanks to the efforts of Bernie Babcock.

The Museum of Science and Natural History combined with the Little Rock Children's Museum in 1997 to create the Arkansas Museum of Discovery, relocating to a historic building in the Little Rock River Market District. The MacArthur Museum of Arkansas Military History was established on May 19, 2001, in the Tower Building. Its mission is to educate visitors about Arkansas' military history, safeguard the Tower Building, pay tribute to American service members, and recognize the birth site of Douglas MacArthur.

Cicely Mary Barker (28 June 1895 – 16 February 1973) was a renowned English illustrator celebrated for her enchanting illustrations of fairies and flowers. Barker's artistic journey commenced during her youth through distance learning and formal training at the Croydon School of Art. She ventured into the professional realm by creating greeting cards and illustrations for children's magazines. In 1923, she achieved a milestone with the publication of her inaugural book, Flower Fairies of the Spring, marking the beginning of a series of similar publications in the ensuing years.

Barker, a committed Anglican, generously contributed her artwork to support Christian causes and missions. She created several Christian-themed publications like The Children's Book of Hymns and, in partnership with her sister Dorothy, He Leadeth Me. Additionally, she crafted a stained glass window for St. Edmund's Church in Pitlake and her painting of the Christ Child titled The Darling of the World Has Come was acquired by Queen Mary.

Barker was skilled in various mediums such as watercolor, pen and ink, oils, and pastels. Her work was mainly influenced by Kate Greenaway and the Pre-Raphaelites. She preferred to paint based on instinct rather than following artistic doctrines. Barker passed away in 1973. While she had previously published Flower Fairy books centered around spring, summer, and autumn, a collection based on winter was not released until 1985, compiled from her unpublished works and published posthumously.

Barker, the second daughter and youngest child of Walter Barker, a partner in a seed supply company and an amateur artist, and his wife Mary Eleanor (Oswald) Barker, was born on 28 June 1895 at their residence on 66 Waddon Road in Croydon, Surrey, England. She suffered from epilepsy during her childhood and received dedicated care from her parents initially, and later from her older sister Dorothy Oswald Barker, who was two years her senior.

The family of four was comfortably situated within the upper middle class bracket. They employed a nanny, governess, and a cook to cater to Barker's specific dietary needs. Barker, who spent a significant amount of time in bed, entertained herself at home with painting books and a nursery library stocked with the creations of Kate Greenaway and Randolph Caldecott, both of whom significantly impacted her future artistic endeavors.

Barker engaged in art correspondence studies, likely until around 1919. At the age of 13 in 1908, she enrolled in an evening program at the Croydon School of Art and continued her studies there through the 1940s. Eventually, she secured a teaching role at the school.

In 1911, Raphael Tuck & Sons purchased four of Barker's "little drawings" for half a sovereign and released them as postcards. By October 1911, she secured the second prize in the Croydon Art Society's poster contest and was soon after appointed as the youngest member of the Society. The art critic from the Croydon Advertiser noted, "Her sketches display an extraordinary sense of liberation. She exhibits clear potential."

After her father passed away in June 1912, the seventeen-year-old Barker contributed her art and poetry to various publications such as My Magazine, Child’s Own, Leading Strings, and Raphael Tuck annuals to help provide for her mother and sister. Dorothy, her sister, worked as a kindergarten teacher at two private schools and later established a home-based kindergarten, which not only generated income for the family but also involved managing household responsibilities.

Fairies gained widespread popularity in art and literature during the early 20th century after the publications of Sir Arthur Conan Doyle's The Coming of the Fairies, J.M. Barrie's Peter Pan, and the fairy-themed creations of Australian artist Ida Rentoul Outhwaite. Queen Mary further popularized these themes by sending Outhwaite's postcards to her friends in the 1920s. Additionally, in 1918, Barker developed a series of postcards featuring elves and fairies.

In 1923, Barker submitted her illustrations of flower fairies to multiple publishers. Blackie purchased 24 paintings along with verses for £25. However, Barker did not start receiving royalties for her work until the release of Flower Fairies of the Summer in 1925. In April of the same year, Mary Violet Clayton Calthrop, the wife of author Dion Clayton Calthrop, praised Barker's work on Flower Fairies of the Spring, noting her exquisite taste and drawing skills.

In 1924, the family relocated to a four-story, semi-detached Victorian residence at 23 The Waldrons. Barker had a studio constructed in the garden, while her sister ran a kindergarten in a room at the rear of the house. The family practiced frugal living and frequented St. Edmund's and St. Andrew's in Croydon, which were considered "low" churches catering to the less affluent. Barker occasionally included depictions of her fellow church members in her religious artworks. Canon Ingram Hill referred to her as a key figure at St. Andrew's church.

The children from the kindergarten posed as models for the Flower Fairies until its closure in 1940. In a 1958 interview, Barker mentioned, "I utilized my sister's kindergarten students as models. I was surrounded by children for many years, an experience I cherished." Besides, she depicted the children of her relatives and even Gladys Tidy, the Barkers' young housekeeper, who inspired the Primrose Fairy in 1923. Barker meticulously painted the plants from real-life specimens, occasionally seeking assistance from Kew Gardens for specific samples. She personally crafted and tailored the Flower Fairy outfits, drawing inspiration from the flowers and leaves corresponding to each illustration. These costumes, stored in her studio trunk alongside twig and gauze wings, were disassembled after each use, with parts repurposed for new designs. Barker frequently consulted Dion Clayton Calthrop's English Costume for reference.

By the late 1920s, Barker started questioning whether her efforts for the church were sufficient and contemplated dedicating herself entirely to religious compositions. Encouraged by her family and friends, she opted to pursue both sacred and secular music endeavors.

Barker persevered with her evening studies at the Croydon Art School from the 1920s through the 1940s, leading to a role as a teacher. She embarked on sketching expeditions to Amberley, Storrington in Sussex, Cornwall, and the southern coast in the company of loved ones. Furthermore, she made visits to Gomshall, Surrey, where she stayed with the artist Margaret Tarrant, and to Ugglebarnby near Whitby, North Yorkshire, to spend time with her family.

In 1940, after their live-in maid retired, the Barker family's routine changed. Dorothy Barker shut down her school located at the rear of their residence on The Waldrons but took on the responsibility of overseeing the household affairs and providing care for both her mother and sister. Dorothy and her sister collaborated on the creation of two books together: "Our Darling's First Book" and the Christian-themed "He Leadeth Me." Unfortunately, Dorothy passed away in 1954 due to a heart attack. Subsequently, Barker found it challenging to dedicate time to her artistic pursuits following her sister's demise, as she had to take on the sole responsibility of looking after her elderly mother. Nevertheless, she did initiate the conceptualization of a stained glass window design in memory of her sister for St. Edmund's in Pitlake.

After Barker's mother passed away in 1960, she relocated from 23 The Waldrons to 6 Duppas Avenue in Croydon in 1961. She renovated a maisonette in Storrington, Sussex, England, gifted to her by Edith Major, and called it St. Andrew's. Following her move, her health started to decline, requiring frequent stays in nursing and recovery facilities, where she received care from loved ones and companions.

Barker passed away at the age of 77 on 16 February 1973 at Worthing Hospital. Following her death, two separate funeral services took place, one at Storrington Church and another at her maisonette. Her remains were laid to rest in Storrington churchyard. In 1989, Frederick Warne, which has been a part of Penguin Books since 1983, obtained ownership of the Flower Fairies properties.

Barker primarily used watercolor combined with pen and ink for her artwork, but she also demonstrated proficiency in black-and-white illustrations, oils, and pastels. She always had a sketchbook handy to portray captivating children. In expressing her artistic approach, she mentioned, "I have consistently aimed to paint in a spontaneous manner that feels innate to me, without much consideration for artistic principles."

Kate Greenaway was a significant influence on Barker's art, as she admired Greenaway since her childhood. Barker's depictions of children in clothing reminiscent of Greenaway's designs, although less somber and with more depth, possibly due to technological advancements in printing. Barker had a keen eye for studying flowers and was close friends with fellow children's illustrator Margaret Tarrant. In addition to Greenaway, Barker drew inspiration from the works of illustrator Alice B. Woodward.

Barker acknowledged a significant and enduring impact from the Pre-Raphaelites. She mentioned being influenced by them, particularly in terms of subject matter, and the emotions and ambience they were able to convey, rather than their techniques. She expressed an admiration for the early works of John Everett Millais and the exceptional art of Edward Burne-Jones.

Barker distributed her sketches, drawings, and paintings of children as gifts to friends, families of the children, charitable organizations, and church events. Her works were also showcased by various art groups. Additionally, she provided illustrations for magazine covers, dust jackets, and created postcard series for publishers like Raphael Tuck. Some of her notable works include "Picturesque Children of the Allies" (1915), "Seaside Holidays" (1918), and "Shakespeare's Boy and Girl Characters" (1917, 1920). Her original books "Old Rhymes for All Times" (1928) and "The Lord of the Rushie River" (1938) received positive critical reception. "Groundsel and Necklaces" (1943) narrates the story of Jenny, who, through the help of fairies, lifts her family out of poverty in a setting around 1800, featuring a character akin to Dickens' Scrooge. "Simon the Swan," conceived as a follow-up to Rushie River in 1943 but fully developed in 1953, was posthumously published in 1988 and is considered less successful than Groundsel.

Barker, a dedicated Christian, created religious-themed artworks throughout her lifetime. She crafted eight postcards and five guardian angel birthday cards for the Society for Promoting Christian Knowledge in 1916 and 1923, respectively. Over a span of 20 years, she designed Christmas cards for The Girls' Friendly Society, with the initial three designs selling a total of 46,500 copies in 1923. Queen Mary acquired an original design titled "The Darling of the World Has Come" for ₤5.50 in 1926. Additionally, the Croydon Art Society displayed Barker's booklet cover design for the Society for the Propagation of the Gospel at its November 1919 exhibition.

Religious-themed publications by the artist include The Children's Book of Hymns (1929) and He Leadeth Me (1933), the latter of which was a collaborative effort with her sister. Notable religious artworks consist of the oil triptychs, The Feeding of the Five Thousand (1929), created for the chapel in Llandaff House in Penarth, Wales, and The Parable of the Great Supper (1934) for St. George's Chapel in Waddon. Although The Feeding piece is no longer extant, a black-and-white photograph from 1929 serves as a reproduction of the original. In 1941, she finished oil panels illustrating the seven sacraments for the baptismal font at St. Andrew's in South Croydon. The artist also designed baptismal rolls for the wall behind the font in 1948 and 1962. In 1946, she completed a 4 x 7 ft. oil painting titled Out of Great Tribulation for the Memorial Chapel at Norbury Methodist Church. After her sister's passing in 1954, the artist commenced work on a design for a stained glass memorial window portraying Christ about to wash his disciples' feet. This final religious-themed creation was installed in St. Edmund's in Pitlake in 1962.
